comments.body: Is this a new approach or just a bug fix?  Is the key already used when the document is added to the registry?
This is not new approach as you see the method already exists and if you browse of other usages of methods of DocumentRegistry you would notice that they all use path and key.
Possibly a dumb question, but doesn't the line end at `lineStarts[i+1] - 1`?
Technically yes, but there are some considerations that the method already implements. e.g. the array is out of bounds.

Can you please double-check the second argument of `substr`?  I'm pretty sure `substr` and `substring` actually do the same thing and treat the second argument as `end` (though I believe sighelp says otherwise).
`substr` uses the second argument as length. Confirmed.
Is this type parameter addition required? Seems strange to now need it.

Here's what's happening: Previously we'd infer `number` from `errorCodes`, then fix that inference as we contextually typed `equateValues`, and finally _ignore_ inferences from `compareValues` because of fixing. Now we defer processing of `equateValues` to get the best possible contextual type, which means we'll infer from both `errorCodes` and `compareValues`. And from `compareValues` we get the candidate `number | undefined` which is technically contravariant, but we ignore that because we're not in `--strictFunctionTypes` mode. So, we end up with a worse inference. The real fix here would be for us to do the work to use `--strictFunctionTypes` in the compiler, the legacy rules just aren't right but it is a breaking change (in other places) to fix them.

It's probably too far gone to change; but is there a good compat reason we can't perform inferences the same way outside and inside `strictFunctionTypes` mode?

But aight, if that's the case I guess it can't be avoided. :(
this is purely stylistic. but i think it read better before. in general refactoring inner pieces of logic that are rather specific to a certain code path makes it harder to understand the flow.

Previously we used switch-case fallthrough to determine whether to reach the last case. That was possible with only two cases, but it's not possible any more when we need two cases to both goto the same third case.
I think these changes are substantial enough to deserve an `organizeImports.ts` file, just like we have for breakpoints/classifier/etc.
All these white-space changes are interesting. Is it passing the linter? (Was it before?)
Yes it is passing linter (before and after). This was done by VS Code formatting, I thought it should be pushed.

Will this block renaming a symbol declared in a default library? I would think that if a symbol is declared in a default library then we shouldn't allow the rename to proceed at all, rather than renaming it in a user's source files and resulting in possible compile time errors.
There's already a feature for that. This will avoid renaming anything on the default library, like comments or strings.

This is simply a peeve of mine, but I don't think that checking for `-1`, specifically, makes sense.  Why not rule out any negative value (i.e. `>= 0`)?  This specific API may be documented to return exactly `-1` (I haven't checked), but many others are not.

My favorite is:

```javascript
  return !!~path.indexOf(somevar); // Note: Overly cute hack. Do not use! :-)
```

Take your time.... I'll wait :wink:

Note in JavaScript it is explicitly a result of -1 if not found (http://es5.github.io/#x15.5.4.7). Simply checking for < 0 seems less correct, in the unlikely event they add other negative values for other scenarios.

While I agree that the meanings of other negative values are unspecified, it seems borderline inconceivable that they could eventually be defined as success cases.  Ruling them out now seems more forward (and slightly-non-compliant implementation) compatible.

From the point of readability `path.indexOf(node_modulesFolderName) !== -1` sucks.

As with any double-negative, you're forced to pause and do some mental calculations: *"ah, it's checking for position, then asserts that position is not good; no wait it asserts that it's not wrong, then proceeds — therefore this statement checks that the substring exists in the path string! Phew...."*

Rules are academic. In the end what counts is cost of maintenance. Replacing `!==-1` with `>=0` improves readability and reduces possibility of bugs.

What if the whole project is situated nested inside node_modules somewhere? Will all TODOs suddenly disappear?

/myDir1/node_modules/myOtherDirectory/**myProjectRoot**/src/blablaFile.ts

1) People do put temporary junk in their node_modules for the purpose of quick-checking someething and avoiding erroneous commit.

2) Additionally, in complex large projects there may be a legitimate need to keep projects in node_modules due to some process optimisation.

All in all, the check should only turn true if node_modules appear after the project root in full path, not before it.
Which brace completions do we still provide and why?
Indeed. I've never liked any completions when typing inside a comment (including braces). Is there a rationale for what we do provide and what we don't?
This behavior mirrors that of CSharp editing in VS. But we can just as easily suppress all completions in comments.

How expensive is this to do for each keypress in a project like Angular? Do we need to employ some type of caching mechanism rather than recalculate this each time?

I did some quick measurements to get an idea about whether this is too much IO. I generated a project with 200 node modules and 150 @ types modules and timed the completions for non-relative (e.g. "some-module-name") and relative (e.g. "../node-modules/") paths. In general, the time for completions was always sub 200 ms. For more reasonably sized directories, the completions are more or less instantaneous. There are rare spikes (up to about 600-700 ms) and I think those are likely due to accessing storage that has fallen out of memory or when the hard drive is in a cold state. Those are pretty rare, however, and after a spike happens you don't see another for a while. For the record, I was timing end-to-end (not just the IO).

Completions shouldn't be triggered on each keypress, just after trigger characters like "/". The caller should handle the filtering of the results until the next trigger character.
Would `isExternalModuleNameRelative` (in utilities.ts) work in place of this function?

Why does this structure have a different shape (optionality) to the EditorOptions above in protocol.d.ts? (Not your code, but the existing fields).

There are default editor options that are applied for TS server so these are all defined as optional in protocol.d.ts in case the user wants to override the defaults. For TS services there are no defaults so the editor options are all required except for the new BaseIndentSize—optional for hosts that want to support base indentation. These two shapes (including differences in case) are reconciled in editorServices.mergeFormatOptions.  @vladima mentioned he is going to make the case consistent with his changes to ts server.

Is this a shim?
No.  It just represents the API we need from the host for the cancellation tokens it provides.

We're calling it "HostCancellationToken" to distinguish it from CancellationToken.  The latter is what we use internally with all our features.  The former is what we get from the host, and what the latter uses to actually make its determinations.

They're not hte same object because the former is used purely for knowing if something should cancel.  The latter is actually responsible for doing the checking _and_ throwing the appropriate script side exception (something the host knows nothing about).

`@deprecated`
Explain that the only caller who cares is rename. It doesn't use definitions, and it doesn't mind if multiple definitions are undefined.
Instead of using the id of relatedSymbol, use its index from searchSymbols, and preallocate all the entries from searchSymbols.
shorthand prop
love it :D
Debug assert that scope is not undefined
We actually don't need to since `undefined` is an acceptable value for `getSymbolsInScope` (i.e. there was no given token, so it will default to the file's globals.
can we just filter instead. this is going to fail anyways. just remove the entries.
This won't crash VS, and I rather have this fixed in the script side to prevent we do unnecessary work there.
i meant to filter on the script side. you know the caller asked for a specific file, so just filter results that are not there.

I think the idea is that we shouldn't be finding more results anyways.  It represents a bug in our code that we should not be trying to workaround.  Instead, we should track down the actual bug and fix it.
Wouldn't you be more curious as to whether the element access is part of the LHS of an assignment?

No.  For example, if you have:

```
foo(a['propname'])
```

we simply want to add 'propname' into the name table any time we see this, so we can effectively do 'Find All Refs' on a property called 'propname'.
Shouldn't this be `previousToken.kind === SyntaxKind.AsKeyword`?
Also, shouldn't isMemberCompletion be `previousToken.kind !== SyntaxKind.AsKeyword`?
What is this used for?
To tell the host if a match is case sensitive or not.  Case sensitive matches of the same kind are considered 'better'.  This is used in VS for sorting items appropriately.
A source file is a declaration?
I guess it has a name
Yup.  And we make a symbol for it.
Huh. For some reason I expected we'd use it more here; we should totally have getOccurrences support for binops
Sure!  That exists in C# and VB today.  Although they get it just by leveraging 'find references'.
templateStack.length = 0
It's actually faster to do it this way.
Explain that rudimentary means 'inexact' and give example of where template classification will be wrong.
i don't understand your comment wrapping.

```
return isTemplate(...)
    ? ...StringLiteral
    : ...Identifier
```
can we turn this into a method getNameTable on SouceFileObject class?
discussed offline: this property will be promoted to method later as a part of general effort to revise API
Isn't it called visitNodes now? Is there a difference between forEachChild and visitNodes?
no, `forEachChild` is still an entrypoint to a traversal routine. `visitNodes` and `visitEachNode` are just helpers that were lifted to a higher scope in order to avoid unnecesary allocations
This seems inappropriate; if we're in a union type, don't we want the union of scopes?
I've considered this and decided not to do so - it will make things more complicated and we will not win a lot
Alright; seems like a good short term strategy. Something to experiment with down the road.
Why is symbol.parent not defined here? Doesn't the checker give union properties a parent?
no, it does not
Why? Maybe it should (for a long term fix).

I believe because union property consists of multiple components (where every component might have a parent) and it makes no sense to speak about a single parent (unless it will be something new to represent union of parents for all constituents)
I thought the parent should just be the union type.
parent should be symbol and union type does not have associated symbol
Ah, you're right, the property I was thinking of was SymbolLinks.unionType
static as well?
There is no valid keyword to show after static, so no completion list.

comments.body:
Super anticlimactic for this review, but could we rename this to `enableIncrementalParsing`?

I think it's only referenced in `tests/cases/unittests/incrementalParser.ts` and `src/harness/fourslash.ts`.

Also, there's a comment on line 1575:

```
// Once incremental parsing is ready, then just call into this function.
```

So just remove that.

I thought about that, but I prefer this.  You are now choosing to opt out of incremental parsing by saying 'yes/true' I would like to disable incremental parsing.

```
-- Cyrus
```

---

From: Daniel Rosenwassermailto:notifications@github.com
Sent: ý12/ý27/ý2014 8:29 AM
To: Microsoft/TypeScriptmailto:TypeScript@noreply.github.com
Cc: Cyrus Najmabadimailto:cyrusn@microsoft.com
Subject: Re: [TypeScript] Enable incremental parsing by default. (#1568)

In src/services/services.tshttps://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/1568#discussion-diff-22292557:

> @@ -1548,7 +1548,7 @@ module ts {
>          return sourceFile;
>      }
> -    export var disableIncrementalParsing = true;
> -    export var disableIncrementalParsing = false;

Super anticlimactic for this review, but could we rename this to enableIncrementalParsing?

—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/1568/files#r22292557.
Is the cost of creating a scanner negligible? I feel like it's pretty uncommon to need this, and you could make it load lazily.

I'm not a fan of lazy loading.  I only really want to do it if there is any actual cost that you need to avoid.  A scanner is pretty much no-cost to create, so i'm fine with just making these up front.
Seems like you could pass in tokenParent, though it doesn't really matter.

Leave a note that while in the common case we need the actual node for correct classifications, in some contexts like the merge conflict scanner, we can use it as what is effectively a multiline lexical classifier.
will do.
Maybe we should add an `else` clause and bail out? Is it better to crash and hope to catch in dogfooding, or let it gracefully do nothing?
interesting, I would not expect names of function expressions to be so special. Why symbol name does not match name in declaration (looks very suspicious to me)?

We bind the symbol name as `"__function"`. Using the symbol is more for convenience. To be quite frank, I'm not sure why we don't just always grab the first declaration with a (non-computed property) name and use that.
Discussed offline
Does a `SourceFile` really have a `Value` meaning? Why is that?
external module. we could check if it is an external module. a comment would be ok as well.
I'll add a comment.
Still feels weird that we're not conditionally saying it's a value unless we specifically check if it's a SourceFile, but if we run into it later down the road, we'll deal with it then.
IsLet ?
Should not this be a new kind consEnumElment
I modified the enum to show in display info as const enum the icon is same.. Will investigate if we can have different icon for constness

`getContainingObjectLiteral*If*ApplicableForCompletion`

or

`tryGetContainingObjectLiteral`.
again, this seems weird that you need to manually do this search.
It's not really clear what is going on for someone running into the code for the first time. I didn't figure it out until I read the assertion. Please add a quick comment.

Is there a particular question you want answered? Basically, we start with a Fidelity node, and we have to find the corresponding AST node. @mhegazy said he is working on removing the Fidelity part, so that might make it clearer.
Right, I just mean a quick comment explaining that we are trying to find corresponding AST nodes for fidelity nodes.
Does this not need to be specialized at all?

It may need to be specialized. One interesting case that may break with this code is:

``` TS
var v: { x: number } = { }/*cursor*/
```

We would certainly not want to get member completion there.
I think this is related to #764. I will get this fixed next.

We are getting this set already in getPossibleSymbolReferencePositions, we can make find all refs add the additional locations in a list(s) to be analyzed later instead of doing two extra passes over all the files.
in addition we need to add the check for the cancellation token.
Fold into one line.
What about `<<`?
We actually don't recognize << as a less than token for generics. We _do_ recognize >> however.
Ah, right; you'll need a case for `>>` and `>>>`.
The lexer doesn't return those as tokens.  It returns the individual > tokens.  It's up to the parser to call abck into the scanner to ask it to reScanGreaterThan to get those tokens.
We are not walking the body of the function declaration this way, correct? If so we are missing inner functions.
Right, this isn't finished, I was thinking about finishing this at home but I think I need to think out some of the semantics when dealing with incorrect code.
This is going to get the first overload, not the last one. I think we should get the last one.
I would pull the visit function out
Why do we have to recurse here?
Because we need to continue to aggregate things like functions within other functions, and eventually things like class expressions.
we only fall through in certain condition. Could you comment more on this?
I think this is explained decently by the preceding comment about constructor parameters.
? and : should be on the next line.
I would fold this with the previous condition and move it to the canFollow as well
this code looks duplicated.
this looks like duplciated code.
comment that you are explicitly not going into the try block part.
Wherever we do this sort of thing, we need an explicit return type annotation, or maybe a type assertion. I strongly prefer the former.
why? we already have a type annotation in the function return type definition.
I'm personally just bigger on explicit over implicit. Plus, not having that there adds mental overhead of trying to figure out the specific type I'm dealing with.

You might not be big on it, but what do you think of turning these into multiline JSDoc comments?

I think you should be able to find/replace easily with:
VS Search Regex: `(\s+)\*\* (.+) \*/`
VS Replacement String: `$1/**\r\n$1 * $2\r\n$1*/`

Is this really the only way to ask this question?  Is there an easier way to do this, just by asking hte the symbol itself?  For example, does the symbol have any sort of flag indicating it is an External Module?

Alternatively, check if any of the declarations of the symbol have an identifier whose kind is SyntaxKind.StringLiteral.

SyntaxKind.StringLiteral would also include string-keyed property names, which you do want to show in completion (see the block directly below this).

In terms of asking for whether something is an external module, there is only a function isExternalModule, which takes a SourceFile, so that will not help you here. You could write a similar utility for ambient external modules (with quoted names). In order for it to work on a Symbol, you'd want to ask if an arbitrary declaration is an external module, based on whether it is a module and its name has quotes. Why is it sufficient to just ask one declaration? Well, external modules can merge, but only with other external modules. So if one declaration is an external module, they are all external modules.

@CyrusNajmabadi There is no external module flag in the symbol. Another way to check would be to check if one of the declaration of the symbol has kind of module and its name has kind of string literal with double-quoted name. @JsonFreeman I like the idea of having utility for ambient external module
Turned out the text of declaration name get stripped off its double-quote so the only way to check is through symbol
Fair enough
I would add a unit test with a keyword after a dot and a space " x . var" to test this
since you are looking into this, can we lose the onError as well and check the last two characters like we do with stringLiteral to know if it is terminated or not?
Will comment that this is on the syntactic thread
moving code is unpleasant for code reviews :)   Can you make your moves as separate commits in the future?  Thanks!
Might be clearer if you still took the descriptors instead of closing over it, but I don't really mind too much.
this looks like isPunctuation, not isToken.
good point. done.
I'd put `classifySymol` after `processNode` just because it throws me off after not seeing `classifySymbol` being used
Why don't we use compiler in this case?
Because it's a purely syntactic feature.  The comment isn't great (it was copied from elsewhere).  What we should be saying is "doesn't use semantics."
Does this mean that we perform classification over comment text as well? if so why we need to do that
Because we want comments to be green :)
spelling : should
Why do we need sourceFile for input?

This function (as well as some others) might require scanning the original text (usually stored in the `SourceFile`) to give the answer. In general `SourceFile` can be found by walking the tree upwards, however passing it explicitly allows not to pay the price of extra walk.If `SourceFile` is not available at callsite it still can be obtained but usually action at the callsite starts with `SourceFile` so there is not point to have penalty that can be easily avoided.
Is it possible to have a break/continue keyword not parented by a break/continue statement?
The general pattern is to always ensure that the token is not part of a "stray" parse, so that we can be resilient.
Why not combine this group with the ForKeyword group
I considered it, but then the `if` gets too long, and technically you don't need to check if the kind is a for-in/for statement if you have a `do` or `while`.
Then I guess each one can be separate.
I'm not a huge fan of checking `node !== undefined` inside this function. I'd rather force the caller to do it.
This is an `undefined`-propagating helper function that's used quite a bit above. It's local to the function and I'd rather keep it.
why are you searching many different source files for 'this'?
Because at the top level, `this` refers to the same `this` across source files.

The name searchSpaceNode is confusing in this context. Namely, I can't tell between searchSpaceNode and container, which one is the original occurrence, and which one is the occurrence currently being considered.
I can give a comment explaining what `searchSpaceNode` is, but beyond that I don't have a better name.
Not needed
@mhegazy what do you think of removing this?
this is needed by rename. if we do not trim it, renaming foo to bar we will replace a["foo"] with a[bar], which is wrong.
Oh... sneaky!
When would there not be a parent? I guess only if you called isWriteAccess on a SourceFile. I feel like this check shouldn't be necessary.
this will break rename, allowing you to rename "this".
Oh true!!
i would remove this for now.  Until we're ready to decide what it means to both findrefs on 'this' as well as what 'rename this' means.

@ahejlsberg and I felt like renaming `this` isn't so unheard of, but yes, it is currently broken in this implementation - rename will populate the initial text with the symbol name in VS.

What semantics did you have for findAllRefs on `this`? While we don't go out of our way to match `this` across merged declarations, we certainly have fairly predictable results. Thoughts @mhegazy, as we discussed this offline?

this comment should be on the actual parent/hasKind functions.
i still think it's appropriate for you to verify that the node.parent.parent is actually a TryStatement.  Blind casting can lead to some very bad results in the future.
having the check here seems _very very strange_.  It is already typed as a TryStatement, but you're now putting in code that indicates that you may not actually have a TryStatement.
i would check that it's actually the keyword you expect.
Comment that this is only used for object literal properties.
I prefer without the +1
Assert that this is an expression?
Interesting!
Can we move these back to interfaces.

i do not really care for the name that much. and this is used in only one place, so the extra layer of abstraction, is not really useful, i would just put it in getSemanticDiagnostics, to recreate if it does not exist and forget about it.

My preference in avoiding errors is to leave only one way that will do things right. Since accessing variable directly might fail without prior check - then this only was should be "always use function, do not touch the variable"

i somewhat feel like this is the wrong place for this.  We shoudln't ever really get a source file without set parents.  So perhaps we should fix up the .update and createSourceFileFromScriptSnapshot calls to do this instead.  what do you think?
thse don't feel right here.  there should be a general place for these questions.  This should be part of our compiler API after all.

I agree.. any suggestion with the place?
I do not think the typechecker is the right place, I can leave them on the global ts namespace..
These are general syntax helpers.  So they should be in parser, scanner, or some low level file that contains helpers.
"create" -> "created"
soruceFiles --> SourceFiles?
Is this merging with the other `SourceFile`? Why not put this all in a different namespace, have this extend `ts.SourceFile` and avoid having to suffix type names with `Object`?
